Package infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel

Class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.TransferEntropyCommon
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel
        • infodynamics.measures.continuous.kernel.TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculator, ChannelCalculatorCommon, ChannelCalculatorMultiVariate, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, TransferEntropyCalculator, TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer
    public class TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel
extends TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel

    Extends TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel for computing the differential transfer entropy (TE) between two multivariate double[][] time-series of observations using box-kernel estimation. This calculator however only be used to add observation tuples, i.e. (source, destination next state, destination past) one at a time. This allows the user to specify the variable that should be used as the destination past state, for advanced applications (where the state is somehow captured differently to the past embedding vector). As an example, see Wang et al. (2012) below.

    Javadocs are somewhat incomplete since this is a niche class. TODO Finish these properly.

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateKernel (extending TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariate), with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to TransferEntropyCalculatorMultiVariateSingleObservationsKernel().
    • Adds additional initialise(double) and initialiseAllDimensions(int, int, int) options
    • The addition of addSingleObservation(double[], double[], double[]) for adding single observations in.

    TODO Implement dynamic correlation exclusion with multiple observation sets. (see the way this is done in Plain calculator). TODO Think about added error-trapping code to make sure the user only makes one type of addObservations call.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • J.T. Lizier, J. Heinzle, A. Horstmann, J.-D. Haynes, M. Prokopenko, "Multivariate information-theoretic measures reveal directed information structure and task relevant changes in fMRI connectivity", Journal of Computational Neuroscience, vol. 30, pp. 85-107, 2011.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • H. Kantz and T. Schreiber, "Nonlinear Time Series Analysis" (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, MA, 1997).
    • X. R. Wang, J. M. Miller, J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko, and L. F. Rossi, "Quantifying and Tracing Information Cascades in Swarms", PLoS ONE 7, e40084+ (2012).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
